abstract.para: This is a note on joint and several liability. If more than one person takes on liability for the same obligation, the liability of each person may be joint or several or joint and several. See also:

section1.para:
Where more than one person takes on an obligation, their liability may be
Joint, or
Several, or
Joint and several.

Where a party to a contract or deed is made up of more than one person, the nature of the liability of that party will usually be expressly stated. The document will often also deal with the liability of successors in title to the original parties if they are made up of more than one person.

Where a document is silent as to the nature of the liability, then it will be a matter of construction. In general there will be joint liability if two or more people covenant in the same document that they or any one of them will do something or if they covenant generally without using any words of severance.

If A and B jointly agree to pay X £1,000 then X is entitled to £1,000 and may claim the whole amount from either A or B. There is only one obligation. Payment of £1,000 by A will discharge the liability of both A and B. If X releases A from the obligation to pay, then B will also be released.

If A and B severally agree to pay X £1,000 then X is entitled to £1,000 from A and a further £1,000 from B. There are in effect two separate contracts: one between A and X, and one between B and X. If A pays £1,000, B will still owe £1,000.

Sometimes, however, the liability will not be cumulative. This can occur in a property context where an original tenant and later an assignee separately covenant with the landlord to pay the rent. The landlord is only entitled to the rent once.

If A and B jointly and severally agree to pay X £1,000 then X is entitled to £1000 and may claim the whole of it from either A or B. The nature of a joint and several obligation is that:
A and B jointly promise to pay X £1,000;
A promises that X will be paid £1,000 by either A or B; and
B promises that X will be paid £1,000 by either A or B.

There is a joint obligation and separate obligations. However, the obligations are not cumulative and X is entitled to £1,000 in total, not £3,000. Payment of £1,000 by A will discharge the liability of A and B. Despite the separate promises, some of the technical rules on the discharge of joint contractors also apply to joint and several contractors.

section1.title: Discharge of liability
section1.para: There are a number of complex rules that affect the discharge of joint contractors and, somewhat illogically, some of these also apply to joint and several contractors. For example, the release of one joint or joint and several contractor will release the others. Similarly accord and satisfaction with one joint or joint and several contractor will discharge the others. However, the application of these rules depends upon the exact formulation and expression of what the covenantee/creditor purports to do. For example, sometimes a 'release' of one joint or joint and several contractor will be construed as an agreement not to sue and so preserve the position against the other(s); or the terms of an accord and satisfaction with one joint or joint and several contractor may reserve the covenantee/creditor’s rights against the other(s).

section1.title: Section 13, Landlord and Tenant (Covenants) Act 1995
section1.para:
This provides that:
Where 'in consequence of' the 1995 Act, two or more persons become bound by the same covenant, then their liability will be joint and several.
Where 'by virtue of' the 1995 Act, two or more persons are jointly and severally liable and one of those persons is released from the covenant, the release does not extend to any other of those persons. This is subject to section 24(2) which deals with the release (principally) of guarantors.
The Civil Liability (Contribution) Act 1978 will apply as regards one person seeking a contribution from another where they are jointly and severally liable by virtue of the 1995 Act.

section1.title: Property documents
section1.para: Condition 1.2 of both the Standard Conditions of Sale (3rd edition) and of the Standard Commercial Property Conditions (1st Edition) state that 'if there is more than one seller or more than one buyer, the obligations which they undertake can be enforced against them all jointly or against each individually'. This would need clarification and expansion where, for example, there were many sellers each selling a different property.

section1.title: Further reading
section1.para: For further reading see Chitty, Volume I, chapters 17 and 25.
